ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We read just about the entirety of Plutarch's Life of Alexander. Because this was my first engagement with the Greek historians, I learned not only about Alexander the Great but also about the Greek historiographical tradition more broadly. And my understanding of Greek prose got much better!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: I appreciate that the reading assignments were generally not very long, which meant that in many class sessions we were actually able to get through all of the assigned reading, something which I've found to be quite rare in classics. Professor Dillon also provided us with a very useful classics resources masterdoc at the beginning of the semester with access to things like obscure dictionaries; this was very helpful for reading the text and will also continue to be helpful throughout the rest of my studies in classics. I also liked that we read the Greek out loud before we translated things, this was very helpful for feeling the general inflection of the original language.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to any student of Greek who is interested in learning about Greek history from the ancient perspective while improving their own understanding of Greek in the process. Plutarch is admittedly not the most exciting prose author, but the story of Alexander the Great is a very interesting one, and the prose is challenging enough to help develop your Greek without being demoralizing.
